name: carum-carvi
distribution: Throughout the United States (excepting California and Texas east to South Carolina)
edibility: Leaves and seeds are typically eaten, but all parts are edible. Seeds have a spicy flavor; leaves are less spicy, with a parsley-dill flavor.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Crescent shaped seeds, 1/16 of an inch, with 5 ridges. Use as leaves in salads, teas, stews, and soups; seeds for flavoring cookies, breads, salads, and cheeses; roots can be cooked.
flower-description: Umbels of 8 to 15 small white or pink-tinged symmetrical flowers on 8 to 12 inch stems.
leaf-description: Compound leaves, made up of two or more leaflets. Similar in appearance to carrots with finely divided, feathery leaves with thread-like divisions, growing on 8 to 12 inch stems. One compound leaf per node along the stem. Edge of the leaf can be lobed with or without teeth, or entire with no lobe.
uses: Caraway has a long history as a household remedy for digestive issues.
